Award.AwardTitle: Physical Properties of Partially Molten Rocks from Microtomography Experiments and Digital Rock Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Melt generated in the interior of the Earth at plate boundaries plays an important role in the transfer of heat and mass and eventually feeds the volcanic activity of our planet. It is important to better constrain how much melt is present at depth and where it is present. Seismic and electromagnetic measurements provide data to constrain melt distribution but how to convert these data into melt fraction estimates remains a subject of contention. This project will analyze three-dimensional images of the distribution of melt in experimentally produced partially molten rocks and simulate several physical properties of these samples. Results from this study will make it possible to link seismic and electromagnetic data with models of melt transport in the interior of the Earth, which ultimately helps understand how plate tectonics works and the link between mantle processes and volcanic activity.

This study will use synchrotron microtomography to image partially molten mantle rocks in three-dimensions. The samples will be hydrostatically-annealed aggregates that consist of olivine and orthopyroxene in different proportions, and contain melt fractions of 0.005 to 0.20. Digital rock physics simulations will be performed to obtain permeability, electrical conductivity and elastic moduli of both hydrostatically annealed olivine + orthopyroxene-basaltic melt and sheared partially molten olivine rocks. Variation of melt content with distance in the sample will be analyzed to constrain the bulk viscosity of the sample. This project will quantify the effects of lithological partitioning due to the presence of orthopyroxene on melt distribution and show how deformation affects melt distribution, and induces permeability anisotropy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial melting at ocean ridges, subduction zones and hotspots plays an important role in the transfer of heat and mass from the upper mantle to the crust. Rate of melt ascension is controlled by the permeability of the partially molten regions of the upper mantle. Geochemistry data of mid-ocean ridge basalt and geological observations of dunite bodies in ophiolite suggest that magma transport beneath mid-ocean ridges is through a network of melt rich channels. To date, there is little quantitative constraint on the permeability of the partially molten mantle rocks with channelized melt networks. 

In this study, we use a digital rock physics approach to quantify the permeability of partially molten rocks containing melt-rich bands. We obtained high-resolution, 3-dimensional (3D) images of partially molten samples encompassing several melt-rich bands (Zhu et al., 2017). The high resolution tomographic datasets allow us, for the first time, to quantify the permeability and 3D melt distribution of the partially molten rocks with heterogeneous melt distribution (Bader et al., 2019). We conducted Stokes flow simulations on the digital rock and calculated the permeability tensor of the digital rock. We found spatial variations in mineralogy can lead to preferential localization of melt on the grain-scale (Miller et al., 2016). Our experimental investigation and digital rock physics simulation provide detailed information of melt network topology (Skemer et al., 2017) and permeability anisotropy (Bader et al., 2019). Through collaborations, the digital rock physics models that we developed were also used to study the 3D distribution of Fe-S liquid under pressure and temperature conditions of the core  (Berg et al., 2017), and the hydration of periclase at near surface conditions (Zheng et al., 2018). The grant provided partial support to 2 PhD students, 3 Master students, and 1 undergraduate senior thesis.  The experimental results are made available through publications, web sites, and presentations.
